Title: Fourier transform is uniformly continuous
Content: I am trying to prove the following statement: If $f \in L^1$, then $\hat f$ is uniformly continuous. The argument given is as follows : $$|\hat f (\xi +h )-\hat f (\xi)| = \left| \int f(x) (e^{-2 \pi i x \cdot (\xi+h)}- e^{-2 \pi i x \cdot (\xi)})\mathrm dx \right| \leq 2 \|f\|_{L^1}$$ Now I suppose we have to use the Dominated Convergence Theorem, but I am unable to see to what sequence of functions we apply the theorem to. Any help is greatly appreciated.
AcceptedAnswer:
I don't know if your questions has been answered in full.  For completeness, we apply DCT for the reasons you mentioned in your post.  The punchline of the story is: $$\begin{align}
\left|\widehat{f}(\xi + h) - \widehat{f}(\xi)\right|  &=  \left| \int f(x) \left(e^{-2 \pi i x \cdot (\xi + h)} - e^{-2 \pi i \xi \cdot x} \right)dx \right|
\\
&\leq \int |f(x)| \left|e^{2 \pi i x \cdot h} - 1  \right| dx
\end{align}$$ which tends to zero as $h \to 0$, and this is enough to show uniform continuity.
